description: The Automatic Top-Up section allows organizations to set automatic top-up rules for their wallets.

description: The Cost Breakdown chart shows breakdown of costs per resource.

title: Images
description: Images are pre-configured templates containing all dependencies, tools and environment settings you need inside of your Daytona Sandbox.

title: Creating Images
description: When spinning up a Sandbox, Daytona uses a simple image with some useful utilities pre-installed, such as `python`, `node`, `pip` as well as some common pip packages.

description: To use an Image that is not publicly available, you need to start by adding the image's private Container Registry:

title: Language Server Protocol
description: The Daytona SDK provides Language Server Protocol (LSP) support through Sandbox instances.

description: Daytona SDK provides an option to create LSP servers using Python and TypeScript.

description: Daytona SDK provides an option to create LSP servers for various languages through the `LspLanguageId` enum in Python and TypeScript.

description: LspLanguageId.

title: LSP Features
description: Daytona SDK provides various LSP features for code analysis and editing.

title: Code Completion
description: Daytona SDK provides an option to get code completions for a specific position in a file using Python and TypeScript.

title: Log Streaming
description: When executing long-running processes in a sandbox, you’ll often want to access and process their logs in **real time**.

title: Asynchronous
description:
If your sandboxed process is part of a larger system and is expected to run for an extended period (or indefinitely),
you can process logs asynchronously **in the background**, while the rest of your system continues executing.

title: Synchronous
description:
If the command has a predictable duration, or if you don't need to run it in the background,
you can process log stream synchronously.

title: Organizations
description: Organizations in Daytona are a way to group resources and easily collaborate with other users.

title: Organization Roles
description: Users within an Organization can have one of two different **Roles**: `Owner` and `Member`.

title: Administrative Actions
description: Organization `Owners` can perform administrative actions such as:

title: Inviting New Users
description:
As an Organization `Owner`, to invite a new user to your Organization, navigate to the _Members page_,
click on _Invite Member_, enter the email address of the user you want to invite, and choose a **Role**.

title: Available Assignments
description: The list of available **Assignments** includes:

title: Managing Invitations
description:
To view their pending invitations to join other Organizations, users can navigate to the _Invitations
page_ by expanding the dropdown at the bottom of the sidebar, and clicking on _Invitations_.

title: Settings
description: The Settings subpage in the Dashboard allows you to view the Organization ID and Name and to delete the Organization if you don't need it anymore.

title: Preview & Authentication
description: Processes listening for HTTP traffic in port range `3000-9999` can be previewed using preview links.

title: Process and Code Execution
description: The Daytona SDK provides powerful process and code execution capabilities through the `process` module in Sandboxes.

description: Daytona SDK provides an option to execute code in Python and TypeScript.

description: Daytona SDK provides an option to run code snippets in Python and TypeScript.

description: Daytona SDK provides an option to execute shell commands and manage background processes in Sandboxes.

description: Daytona SDK provides an option to execute shell commands in Python and TypeScript.

description: Daytona SDK provides an option to start and stop background processes.

description: Daytona SDK provides best practices for process and code execution in Sandboxes.

description: Daytona SDK provides an option to troubleshoot common issues related to process execution and code execution.

title: Sandbox Management
description: Sandboxes are isolated development environments managed by Daytona.

title: Creating Sandboxes
description: Daytona SDK provides an option to create Sandboxes with default or custom configurations.

title: Basic Sandbox Creation
description: Daytona SDK provides methods to create Sandboxes with default configurations, specific languages, or custom IDs using Python and TypeScript.

title: Create a Sandbox with specific language
Create a Sandbox with custom ID
Sandbox Resources
description: You can configure the compute resources allocated to your Sandbox using the `SandboxResources` class.

title: Create a Sandbox with custom resources
Sandbox Information
description: Daytona SDK provides methods to get information about a Sandbox, such as ID, root directory, and status using Python and TypeScript.

title: Get the root directory of tha Sandbox user
Get the Sandbox name, image and state
description: To get the preview URL for a specific port, check out Preview & Authentication.

title: Remove Sandbox
description: Daytona SDK provides methods to perform operations on Sandboxes, such as removing Sandboxes using Python and TypeScript.

title: Sandbox States and Persistence
description: Daytona keeps the filesystem in its entirety during the Sandbox lifecycle.

title: Auto-stop Interval
description: It is important to understand the Sandbox states to maintain cost-effectiveness.

title: Running
description: Running Sandboxes utilize CPU, memory, and disk storage.

title: Stopped
description: Stopped Sandboxes only utilize disk storage.

title: Archived
description: When Sandboxes are archived, the entire filesystem state is moved to very cost-effective object storage, making it possible to keep Sandboxes available for an extended period.

title: Performance Considerations
description: The tradeoff between archived and stopped states is that starting an archived Sandbox takes more time, depending on its size.

title: CLI
description: The `daytona` command-line tool provides access to Daytona's core features including managing images and the lifecycle of Daytona Sandboxes.

description: Print the version number

description: Get sandbox info

description: List sandboxes

description: Start a sandbox

title: daytona sandbox stop
description: Stop a sandbox

description: Manage Daytona sandboxes

description: Create a new sandbox

description: Manage Daytona MCP Server

description: Start Daytona MCP Server

title: daytona mcp config
description: Outputs JSON configuration for Daytona MCP Server

title: Usage
description: The Usage subpage in the Dashboard shows usage limits assigned to Organizations.

title: CPU Quota
description: The CPU Quota is the maximum number of CPU cores that can be used by Sandboxes in an Organization.

title: Memory Quota
description: The Memory Quota is the maximum amount of RAM that can be used by Sandboxes in an Organization expressed in gigabytes.

title: Disk Quota
description: The Disk Quota is the maximum amount of disk space that can be used by Sandboxes in an Organization expressed in gigabytes.

title: Sandboxes/Running Sandboxes Quota
description: The Sandboxes Quota is the maximum number of Sandboxes that can be created in an Organization.

title: Images/Total Image Size Quota
description: The Images Quota is the maximum number of Images that can be created in an Organization.

title: Volumes
description: Volumes are FUSE-based mounts on the Sandbox file system that enable file sharing between Sandboxes and instant access to existing files already present on the mounted volume.

title: Creating Volumes
description: In order to mount a volume to a Sandbox, one must be created.

title: Mounting Volumes to Sandboxes
description: Once a volume is created, it can be mounted to a Sandbox by specifying it in the `CreateSandboxParams` object:

title: Create a new volume or get an existing one
Mount the volume to the sandbox
When you're done with the sandbox, you can remove it
The volume will persist even after the sandbox is removed
Deleting Volumes
description: When a volume is no longer needed, it can be removed.

title: Working with Volumes
description: Once mounted, you can read from and write to the volume just like any other directory in the Sandbox file system.

title: Limitations
description: Since volumes are FUSE-based mounts, they can not be used for applications that require block storage access (like database tables).

title: Web Terminal
description: Daytona provides a Web Terminal for interacting with your Sandboxes, allowing for a convenient way to view files, run commands, and debug.
